29.52.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
forget Starsky and Hutch, Cagney and Lacey,

35.68.text:
Crockett and Tubbs - we have our own fox shooting
double act it is Gilchrist and Lupton.

42.87.text:
We've got more gundog training tips thanks
to Skinners Pet foods.We've got news stump,

48.77.text:
we have got hunting youtube, but first we're
after some trade secrets from ferreting aficionado

57.17.text:
Simon Whitehead is a professional ferreter
- that's part pest controller, part clown,

61.95.text:
part poet and part transportation engineer.
When he's not sorting out the local rabbit

66.70.text:
population he's writing for Shooting Times
or keeping us entertained around game fair

73.19.text:
Today we find him in Norfolk on a new piece
of ground that needs the Whitehead touch.

78.39.text:
It's not crop damage they're worried about,
it's people breaking their ankles in rabbit

82.59.text:
holes on these overspill car parks. And he
takes the job very seriously.

87.66.text:
You have got to be clinical, you have got
to be single minded and a bit selfish, because

92.09.text:
all I want to do is catch these rabbits. So
if it means putting 100 nets down, 200 nets

97.25.text:
down, if it means getting the dogs out, if
it means me shooting at night and staying

99.93.text:
here all night or trapping it. That is what
I will do to get the job done. Because at

104.18.text:
the end of the day we are working for a reputation
and that reputation will take decades and

110.00.text:
decades to build, but if you don't do your
job you will destroy it in about 30 seconds.

114.97.text:
Joining Simon today are Digger, Torchy, Sean,
Milly and, of course, Simon's patriotic ferrets.

122.32.text:
Like all working animals they have their strengths
and weaknesses. Simon chooses which ones to

128.85.text:
But with ferrets it is your glass half full,
your glass half empty, because if we are working

134.47.text:
under roads you don't want a ferret that is
going to stay there all day with a rabbit

138.76.text:
where as I do here. So you tend to know how
the ferrets work. Some work and some don't

145.44.text:
work no matter how well the brain. So you
are continually having a turn over of stock

150.83.text: to pick the best one to breed from.

153.33.text:
After a couple of cappuccinos (all media ferreters
drink cappuccino these days - didn't you know?),

158.32.text:
we're caffeined up for the first assault of
the day - a bank riddled with holes. Simon

163.68.text:
directs the troops. All escape routes are
covered in purse nets - and woe betide anyone

169.01.text:
who lets a rabbit escape. Simon does not like
runners.

172.83.text:
The rabbits start popping out and some get
a helping hand - with ferret still in tow.

179.26.text:
It seems to be a point about there where you
press which seems to make their jaws open.

184.28.text:
You have got to be humane with the rabbits
and deal with them and then sort the ferret

194.90.text:
Milly is supposed to be on Simon's side of
the fence for any mopping up, but seeing all

198.76.text:
the fun's on the other side, she gets involved
...

201.77.text: Milly has got it. She has got it.

204.83.text:
Another healthy rabbit is added to the tally
which will be about what today Mr Whitehead??

210.64.text:
Well, I want every rabbit here really, but
I know it is not going to happen. But we are

217.38.text:
going to try. Don't know ... what do you reckon
Shaun, 40? Between 30 and 40. Then you might

223.39.text:
see Whitehead smile. Any less and you will
see a grimace. Is that about right?

227.65.text:
I don't mind. How ever many we catch the important
thing is they don't escape.

236.42.text: We don't mention that word, not escapees.

239.18.text:
Oh dear, spoke too soon and we have an escapee.
Digger gets a yellow card. Simon knows, however,

248.37.text:
Back netted. It has come out of there, slipped
digger and come down there, so ... get him

259.68.text:
out dispatch him. We will have to tell Digger
now that we have recinded his yellow card

271.25.text: so he is safe for another day.

273.61.text:
Having worked the bank we cross to the hedge
line. With so many holes we play the numbers

278.27.text:
game hoping to film that bunny rocketing out
of the the bury. This one has a quick peek

283.03.text:
- and decides the other way is better. Oops.
Bad decision.

287.82.text:
Having had some bolting bunnies to start with,
they now seem to be holding tight. The ferret

292.56.text:
finders work brilliantly. Simon locates the
ferret then extricates the rabbit. He is well

298.18.text:
known for his Inspector Gadget-like arms,
reaching rabbits others fail to grasp, though

303.61.text: even he needs some extra length now and again.

308.63.text:
Yeah ... I am going to try in there ... let
me get a stick.

325.53.text:
So that stick will go under and you will feel
the fur and when you draw it out you will

331.20.text:
have a bit of fur on the stick so you will
know there is a rabbit in there. Your arm

335.30.text:
will reach that far, with a stick you can
reach that far, just in case there is another.

342.07.text:
With a bit more digging Sean offers to have
a quick go at the bank but soon regrets it.

346.84.text: We lose a rabbit and he gains a golf club.

349.27.text:
He is grumpy now because he missed a rabbit
so he has got his golf club, second rabbit,

354.50.text:
God forbid it, will give him a golf ball,
then a T and if he does it four times we will

359.16.text: get his membership and he won't be ferreting.

363.59.text: Lunchtime and Torchy show us his swing.

367.37.text: That is what happens when cousins make love.

371.49.text: Because of the government's lack of care.

374.32.text: That is the result, that is the result.

375.97.text:
What this is the government cut back of the
care in the community. They would be locked

380.42.text:
up with duvet wall paper, but now we have
got to take him out.

387.10.text: OK Sean lets leave it there.

389.89.text:
Now we said we were going to bring you a few
tips and tricks of the trade. Here's one to

394.13.text:
play with. The Donk Board. It's a bit like
pinball for rabbits. If successful, it keeps

401.36.text:
Especially if we are shooting the ... rabbits
it makes sense because we can't get a stock

405.21.text:
net through there. So the rabbits are going
to feel safe. So with this board hopefully,

409.79.text:
they will run up, hit it, it goes dong. Two
seconds later we know it is going to come

414.64.text:
out. It is going to come out that side or
this side. We are going to put a lovely great

420.53.text:
stock net along there across the top and the
bottom to try and persuade them to come out

425.38.text: and get Milly to stretch her legs.

427.31.text:
The Donk Board is ideal for this hedge as
netting would be a real pain. Anyway, let's

431.44.text:
give it a go. And, for a but of fun, we've
put a camera on Milly.

435.95.text:
Our first rabbit does bolt but hits one of
the few nets and Milly soon hits it.

440.65.text:
Catching a rabbit in a net you have got to
be careful of the back claws. You can get

444.11.text:
a claw through and will cause serious damage
to your hand. So make it quick and make sure

450.39.text:
you keep an eye on those claws. Because those
claws are razor sharp. They are razor sharp

458.31.text:
Then we get a couple that give Milly something
to chase - the rabbit is out in the open field

462.61.text:
and beats Milly to the fence. This is similar
to baseball. It heads back down the fence,

467.36.text:
hits the Donk Board, knocks it over and makes
a home run.

471.83.text:
The second runner follows the hedge - is turned
back by the Donk Board - comes back again

481.39.text:
Milly loses the camera and finally makes contact
with a rabbit. It has the scars to show that

486.31.text:
it's been trying to wait it out at a stop
end.

490.05.text:
It is in a dead end that is what is being
presented to the ferret and it is trying to

496.74.text:
The boys persist. Each dig delivers a rabbit.
It's labour intensive but that's the way Simon

502.16.text:
operates. For him, this is not sport. He needs
to disrupt the population dynamics of these

507.66.text: bunnies and that means a multi-pronged approach.

509.84.text:
Country people have proved it time and time
again. By hiding, ferreting, shooting and

514.70.text:
other methods together, what you don't get
with one you will get with another. It is

521.70.text:
about upsetting their natural cycle, their
balance, their breeding stock their numbers.

526.72.text:
It is about destroying their territory because
otherwise they are going to regroup and start

533.73.text:
In all we bag 31 rabbits with the ferrets.
Simon's now going out with the night vision

538.84.text: and air rifle to upset things even more.

542.19.text:
Simon Whitehead: he takes no prisoners, never
plays golf, and always gets his rabbit.

548.67.text:
Well we have of course made lots of ferreting
and lurcher type films if you can see that

553.88.text:
screen up there on youtube and you click on
it you can go through and watch some of them.

557.34.text:
Now it is over to David on the Fieldsports
Channel News Stump.

570.92.text:
Shooters are helping the Red Squirrel Trust
in Wales. BASC has hooked up with the organisation

576.60.text:
to shoot grey squirrels in Gwynned. The two
organisations already work together in Anglesey

581.17.text:
which now contains the largest and most genetically
diverse red squirrel population in Wales with

587.04.text:
more than 500 animals Squirrel Nutkins living
a grey-free life.

592.22.text:
Staying with squirrels and there are more
than fifty shades of grey, with this one from

596.25.text:
near Edinburgh at one extreme of the spectrum.
The albino squirrel has had an outing in the

602.09.text:
Daily Mail, which reported that it is called
Albert. At the other end of the scale, black

606.78.text:
versions of the grey squirrel, common in East
Anglia, may recolour grey squirrels permanently,

611.80.text:
according scientists, because the black gene
is dominant.

616.10.text:
George Digweed has kicked the new clay season
off in style with a hard-fought win in South

621.00.text:
He won gold after a sudden death shoot out
against fellow brit Mark Marshall. After the

626.63.text:
win George said that this season looks set
to be one of the most hard-fought ever, and

633.55.text:
It's bad news for duck in the USA. A state
game & parks commission is expecting a population

639.43.text:
crash because duck hunter numbers are falling.
From a high of more than 2 million in the

645.43.text:
1970s, only 1.3 million duck hunting ‘stamps'
- as the licence is known - were sold in 2012.

651.72.text:
This means less money for conservation of
waterfowl habitat.

657.19.text:
Police are investigating after a fox was attacked
by hounds on a busy main road in the Carmarthenshire

662.72.text:
Hunt country. A passenger on a bus took this
photograph and posted it anonymously to the

668.47.text:
Spotted Carmarthen Facebook group. The Carmarthenshire
Hunt was 20 miles away at the time, with police

677.87.text:
The Zambian hunters organisation says it welcomes
the country's one-year ban on hunting in the

682.78.text:
country. The Resident Hunters Association
of Zambia says the ban will ‘bring sanity

687.54.text:
to the hunting industry' after what it calls
‘a lot of confusion in the wildlife sector'

694.99.text:
And finally, Daddy-O's Frozen Yoghurt store
in Medford, New Jersey got a shock this week.

700.97.text:
A deer crashed through the window, knocked
over some chairs and then crashed out again.

709.49.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

723.31.text:
Thank you David. Now that crazy, limey shoot
boy Mark Gilchrist tends to fly solo when

728.51.text:
he is out at night with a gun, but this time
he is taking with him legendary ace Roy Lupton.

735.39.text:
You ever get that feeling it's going to be
a long night? - it doesn't start well - low

740.63.text:
fuel in the Argo means a trip to the nearest
petrol station. Then Mark starts talking about

749.77.text:
Billabong or something like that, apparently
it is the height of fashion.

757.89.text:
Apparently it has that lovely Lenor fresh
smell. Then they just get covered in ...

763.24.text:
It's so cold tonight that it's all about layers.
A promising night's foxing can quickly be

768.65.text:
ruined without proper thought and consideration
for one's attire.

773.27.text:
But it's amazing what a fox in your sights
can do to shut the cold out. One down.

779.60.text:
Perfect shot. Look at that. Perfect. That
is that dog. I thought there would be a dog

795.85.text: here. There we go. One down.

798.78.text:
We're pretty exposed out here on the marshlands.
With no night vision or urban light pollution,

804.47.text:
we could be on the moon. Happily this moon
has foxes. Roy gets on to another.

813.79.text:
Mark marks it using the latest version of
his app. Every fox and rabbit we pick tonight

819.23.text:
will get logged: the date and location will
not only be added to the database but the

823.92.text:
info will also automatically be sent to the
farmer. It's a shame it doesn't record size

829.49.text: as well, as it's a big dog fox.

832.55.text:
Another dog. I am not surprised at that size.
He's huge isn't he.

837.57.text:
Farmer complained that he could hear them
the other night and I managed to miss one

842.07.text:
the other day. A spot about 800 yards from
here which is where we are going to go next.

851.78.text:
So I think we might stand a chance of getting
another three or four. Onwards and upwards.

856.52.text:
Our next call produces a great response. A
vixen comes charging in. She's too close for

862.44.text:
the rifle and yet a change of position keeps
her in the game. Roy is chuffed and Mark is

872.17.text:
That vixen just would not stop she came steaming
straight in. We even shouted at her to try

877.16.text:
and stop her, but she wasn't having any of
it and literally just passed in front of the

882.80.text:
argo about 15 yards off. If we had a shot
gun we could have easily dealt with her as

888.11.text:
she ran past us. But luckily she ran passed
and just over the brow. We pulled the argo

894.33.text:
back round and came just over the brow and
caught sight of her again and just gave her

898.59.text:
a little bit of squeak and where she was so
curious and obviously very hungry she gave

903.14.text:
us a second opportunity. Brilliant, yes absolutely
brilliant especially with the white light.

908.38.text:
I love going out with the night vision and
it is great going out with the red filter.

913.54.text:
When you have got foxes which are not lamp
shy what so ever and they are coming in and

917.36.text:
when you have got the white light out. You
just can't beat it because you see so much

921.37.text:
As soon as you put in your mouth I thought
... well you have got more toys than me. I

928.27.text:
don't want to come across as all jealous,
but I thought another gimic but no I am pretty

937.94.text:
Midnight comes and goes. It takes a while
before our next fox, but it's another nice

943.34.text:
one. And now it's surely time to call it a
night?

946.06.text:
Shall we see if there are any more on the
way back.

947.85.text: Oh yes, we are not letting David go to bed.

950.75.text: He is bleating on though isn't he?

953.08.text:
It is childish - you are in the wrong job.
You are in the wrong job. I want to work in

961.61.text:
an office. At ITV we clocked off at five o'clock.
I need a tea break, my bottom hurts. Can I

973.31.text: have a sandwich? Come on David.

976.24.text:
David has asked for it to be known that Gilchrist
finally dragged himself out of his pit the

981.97.text:
following day at 11am when Roy phoned him.
Roy was crying inside the whole time - and

989.32.text: they had a proper seat with leg room.

991.77.text:
Right. On with the film and, well, that's
where it pretty much ends: four foxes on the

996.59.text:
deck with some cracking shooting from Roy.
Gilchrist taking out a few extra bunnies with

1001.55.text:
his night vision when the opportunity presents
itself.

1004.03.text:
A good night really. There are a few more
we are going to have to come back and get

1014.88.text:
another time that just wouldn't play the game.
I think we need to get a rest and there were

1017.59.text:
There are definitely a few more foxes out
there to go and play with. As I say there

1020.73.text:
are one or two there who are lamp shy. We
will get the night vision set up for those

1025.25.text:
and hopefully account for those without too
much bother. I am absolutely bloody frozen.

1030.26.text:
Didn't they do well and if you want to see
more foxing films, click on the screen up

1035.39.text:
Now we are off to look at some kit with Kit
Special.

1043.51.text:
Kit special this week looks again at sporting
guns that we love the most. Here's a quick

1047.38.text:
review of the secondhand guns on the new website
GunsDirect.co.uk that its users have viewed

1053.87.text:
Starting with fullbore rifles - and it is
not the rifle so much as the price. It's a

1057.65.text:
Parker-Hale in .243 screw cut for moderator
for just £200. Founded in 1880 on the promise

1063.51.text:
of delivering more accurate rifles, Parker
Hale was for much of the 20th century a mighty

1071.03.text:
Most popular shotgun is a £150 AYA. The Spanish-made
boxlock non-ejector with 28-inch barrels is

1077.23.text:
choked 3/4 and 1/4. There was a time when
the Birmingham gun trade blamed Spain for

1082.94.text:
Top airgun choice on GunsDirect.co.uk is,
like last week, a BSA Mercury in-------- .22

1089.79.text:
for £145. BSA, one of the titans of the Birmingham
trade alongside Parker Hale, is now owned

1094.86.text:
by Spanish company Gamo. Aha! Or as they say
in Birmingham these days ‘Ole'.

1100.05.text:
That is it. Feast your eyes, fish into your
pockets. Thanks for watching. This is Kit

1105.67.text:
From hardware to our furry friends. We are
learning gun dog training tips thanks to the

1110.49.text:
experts sponsored by Skinners Petfoods makers
of the Field & Trial range of dog food.

1128.37.text:
A pheasant gets up, the shot goes off, the
bird is down, your dog completes a perfect

1133.16.text:
retrieve but then it all goes wrong. How much
displeasure should you show to a dog?

1138.87.text:
Spaniel, Micky, decided he was going to help
him with his lord and unfortunately went to

1145.22.text:
grab it. Den being the sensitive dog that
he is gave it up very, very easily. It is

1150.76.text:
not what I wanted because I have got a wounded
bird I want it back quickly I don't want dogs

1154.81.text:
mouthing it. So as a result Micky got a ticking
off. He is quite a sensitive dog. You tailor

1162.07.text:
your ticking off to your dog. Some dogs need
a firm hand. Some dogs a growl would be more

1169.61.text:
than enough. So the art in training a dog
is knowing what type of dog you have got and

1175.31.text:
what level of pressure it requires. Too much
pressure and you will get the dog worried.

1182.20.text:
Not enough pressure and you are always ticking
the dog off.

1185.57.text:
Now I would say that Micky had a really big
ticking off there from the outside. So that

1190.91.text: is not a big ticking off particularly.

1193.27.text:
The question is, if it is a serious ticking
off the dog is worried when off you go again.

1200.22.text:
If you can see in the video Micky then hunts
on quite happily afterwards. So actually hopefully

1206.17.text:
it is lesson learned, but I haven't squashed
his drive or enthusiasm I have got him that

1212.31.text:
A little bit later on, like a naughty child,
you gave him his retrieve.

1217.70.text:
I gave him his retrieve. The thing is he worked
hard all morning he watched the other dogs

1223.61.text:
having retrieved he is a capable retriever
so I wanted the reward for his efforts was

1230.76.text:
a nice straight forward little pheasant that
he went out and picked very nicely and brought

1235.96.text:
Ricky Moloney runs Ribblesdale Labradors.
This series on gundog training tips is brought

1239.71.text:
to you by Skinners Petfoods, maker of the
Field & Trial range of gundog feeds. Visit

1249.82.text:
From dogs to all kinds of hunting on Youtube.
It is Hunting YouTube.

1259.03.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1263.86.text:
Viewer Laif Mearns contacts us from Australia
to recommend a video by Ben Smith that, he

1268.23.text:
says, speaks for itself and embodies what
most Australian hunters experience. He's bang

1272.24.text:
on there. Outback Hunting Trip 2012-2013:
Pigs and Goats is a cracker. Thank you Laif.

1277.65.text:
Back to the old country, The Decoy Boys, two
friends in the north-east of Ireland (Co Monaghan

1281.47.text:
and Co Louth), are out in this film at the
end of the pheasant season with a red setter.

1285.91.text:
Staying in Erin, James McKiernan of CountrySportsCavan
sends in his latest film showing crows, jackdaws

1290.31.text:
and sheep, and revealing that he isn't actually
allowed to shoot here - but he is proud of

1294.60.text:
his new scopecam, so that's all right then.
He says he is not going to put up another

1298.21.text:
film until we feature this one in Hunting
YouTube. So here it is.

1301.99.text:
Fishing in Iceland, what better company than
the remarkable entrepreneur, angler and environmentalist

1306.23.text:
Orri Vigfússon? Icelandic Angling Club by
Fish Berserk takes us to his four rivers:

1311.11.text:
(once again, forgive the accent) Selá, Hofsá,
Fljótaá and Laxá in Adaldalur.

1317.39.text:
Now we're off to the USA for TN Wild Side
- PJ's First Fish. This is a story about a

1322.63.text:
little boy who gets a surprise on a summer
morning. It just took a few minutes, but it

1326.46.text:
may have changed his life and his parents
say it may have changed theirs too. Wild Side

1330.20.text: Guide Craig Owensby takes us there.

1332.48.text:
Let's go arty. Shotgun impacts in slow motion
by TheSlowMoGuys•is the result of one of

1336.72.text:
their subscribers who wanted to see slow motion
clay pigeon shooting. With the help of Barry

1341.28.text:
the farmer and his shotgun, it is amazing
to see the spread of the lead shot, and the

1345.32.text:
speed that it moves even in slow motion. And
it is a shocking waste of fruit.

1349.95.text:
More arty stuff here. Jan Renaer sends in
a Dutch documentary about shooting, shot in

1355.33.text:
HD at 7,000 images per second. Fieldsports
Channel generally manages a best of 5,000fps.

1360.20.text:
It's only a trailer for a longer documentary
but it's beautiful.

1364.24.text:
Finally, viewer Angel Sancho recommends his
own film which he calls "a nice video about

1368.60.text:
hunting without guns". We are in Spain, hunting
perdices rojas (red-legged partridges) with

1373.78.text:
a halcón peregrino (peregrine falcon) and
an azor (a goshawk).

1378.90.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1381.99.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1387.89.text:
Another film you could watch is the latest
in our new series, School Challenge TV. This

1392.47.text:
week, it takes a look at Schools Challenge
events coming up in 2013. And there is a feature

1397.12.text:
on clay pigeons, clay pigeon traps, and the
technology behind them. It is a YouTube Show,

1402.97.text:
alongside shows such as Top Gear, and there
is a link to it on the screen.

1408.19.text:
Well we are back next week and if you are
watching this on Youtube don't hesitate to

1411.41.text:
hit the subscribe button which is somewhere
on the outside of the screen. Or go to our

1414.03.text:
webpage www.fieldsportschanne.tv where you
can click to like us on Facebook or follow

1417.19.text:
us on Twitter or scroll down to the bottom
of the page and put your email address into

1419.63.text:
our constant contact form and we will be in
touch with you every week about our show which

1424.28.text:
is out at 7pm UK time on Wednesdays. This
has been Fieldsports Britain.
